item.question: What is the purpose of the file <font face="monospace">xdm-config</font> for <font face="monospace">xdm</font>? (Choose the best answer)

It is a graphical tool to configure <font face="monospace">xdm</font>

item.question:
You want to run logrotate on a daily basis. What should you
do to make this possible?
item.choice: Add or edit a configuration in <font face="monospace">/etc/logrotate.d</font>
Use the <font face="monospace">at</font> command to run <font face="monospace">logrotate</font> at a specific time
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands will resolve a hostname to an ip-address? (Choose all correct answers)
item.hint: The question is not which command would you use to resolve a hostname to an ip-address. But which commands do hostname resolving. This means that programs that do accept hostnames and resolve these to ip-addresses to fulfill their task are also correct answers.

item.question: Concerning the exit value of a command, which of the following is true?
item.choice: You can't test for normal execution by checking the exit value.
When the command failed execution the exit value will be 0.
When the command executed succesfully the exit value will be 0.
An exit value other than 0 will result in the shell being terminated.
item.correct_answer: When the command executed succesfully the exit value will be 0.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider the following command:
What will be the result?
item.choice: The primary bash prompt includes the username and hostname
The primary bash prompt includes the current working directory and hostname
The secondary bash prompt includes the username and hostname
The secondary bash prompt includes the username and full hostname
item.correct_answer: The primary bash prompt includes the username and hostname
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:

Which represents the highest priority?

item.question: Which of the following websites are good resources for known security problems, and for obtaining patches and updates for vulnerable applications?
item.hint: Sorry, no hint for this one. You either know 'em or you don't.

item.question: To print a list of mails currently in the queue, which command would you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following BEST describes what the <font face="monospace">/etc/skel</font> directory is used for?
item.choice: When the system boots the contents of the <font face="monospace">/etc/skel</font> directory is read and depending on the runlevel the scripts are executed.
Each time a user logs in the contents of <font face="monospace">/etc/skel</font> is used to initialize the shell environment.
The contents of the directory can be used to provide a default environment when new users are created.
It contains the configuration files for the application <font face="monospace">skel</font>.
item.correct_answer: The contents of the directory can be used to provide a default environment when new users are created.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider the following command:
What does the argument -s do?
item.choice: Specify the default shell for the user <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
Show the account settings for <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
Nothing, as <font face="monospace">useradd</font> does not know about an option <font face="monospace">-s</font>
item.correct_answer: Specify the default shell for the user <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You have the file <font face="monospace">/etc/resolv.conf</font>, but the computer does not use the configured DNS servers to look up host names. What is most likely the problem?
item.choice: The localhost hostname is not properly configured in <font face="monospace">/etc/hosts</font>.
You do not have a <font face="monospace">/etc/named.conf</font> file.
The named daemon is not running on your computer.
The hosts entry in your <font face="monospace">/etc/nsswitch.conf</font> does not list <font face="monospace">dns</font>.
item.correct_answer: The hosts entry in your <font face="monospace">/etc/nsswitch.conf</font> does not list <font face="monospace">dns</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following are true? (Select all correct answers)
item.choice: Port 53 is used by the telnet service.
Port 143 is used by mail user agents to retrieve new mail.
Port 465 is used to provide encrypted HTTP traffic.
Port 25 is used by mail transfer agents to transport mail messages.
item.correct_answer: Port 143 is used by mail user agents to retrieve new mail.
Port 465 is used to provide encrypted HTTP traffic.

item.question: You attached a scsi-device to your system and want to check if the kernel detects the device. Which commandline is BEST to use to see which scsi-devices are connected?
item.hint: The question is about the KERNEL detecting the device and not UDEV. Therefore, the <font face="monospace">/dev</font> directory can be disregarded. The kernel uses a special filesystem to display system information. This filesystem is not located on disk but maintained in memory. However, you can access the contents as if it were normal files and directories on a disk.

item.question: Consider the above exhibit. When the user starts a non-login shell what will be the value of the variable <font face="monospace">EDITOR</font>?
item.hint: All mentioned files in the exhibit are correct. You will need to know which files are read in which order when the user starts a non-login shell.

item.question: The mail transfer agent <font face="monospace">postfix</font> is used on your local system. Which files allow you to redirect e-mail sent to <font face="monospace">guru0</font> to a different e-mail address?
item.hint: An alias is usually used to connect an email address for a non-existing user to an existing user. This user does not have to be a user on the same system. To allow a user to manage his or her own e-mail redirection each user can add a hidden file to forward his or her e-mail to another e-mail address.

item.question: You want the system with hostname <font face="monospace">atc</font> to be able to use your local system to display a graphical application. Which of the following commands would allow ONLY <font face="monospace">atc</font> access to your local Xorg server?
item.hint: With xhost you can grant or deny access for a certain host. With xhost access is added or subtracted.

item.question: Consider above exhibit. Which of the following statements if true?
item.choice: The column <font face="monospace">books</font> will be updated and set equal to <font face="monospace">linux</font>.
The table <font face="monospace">books</font> will be updated wheere <font face="monospace">title</font> equals <font face="monospace">linux</font>.
The table <font face="monospace">title</font> will be updated and all rows in the column <font face="monospace">books</font> will be set to <font face="monospace">linux</font>.
All rows will be updated in the table <font face="monospace">books</font>.
item.correct_answer: All rows will be updated in the table <font face="monospace">books</font>.

item.question: You have replaced <font face="monospace">inetd</font> with <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>. What must be done after installation to ensure that your machine will work correctly?
item.choice: You must add a symbolic link from <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to <font face="monospace">xinetd.conf</font>.
You must convert the file <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to the configuration file format used by <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>.
You don't have to do anything because they are compatible.
You must convert and copy the file <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to <font face="monospace">xinetd.conf</font>
item.correct_answer: You don't have to do anything because they are compatible.

item.question:
On a system with a single network interface you are asked to make sure remotely logged in users are disconnected.
Which command would you use?

You notice that the automatic configuration of <font face="monospace">Xorg</font> fails. You now want to generate a configuration file for <font face="monospace">Xorg</font>. Which of the following commands allows you to generate a template configuration file?
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">xf86config</font> is used by the XFree86 implementation of the X Window System. The question is about the Xorg implementation.

item.question: What can you do to recover a lost passphrase for a DSA or RSA authentication key?
item.choice: Decrypt the authentication key with gpg.
A lost passphrase cannot be recovered.
Decrypt the authentication key with ssh -decrypt.
item.correct_answer: A lost passphrase cannot be recovered.

item.question:
Consider above output from a SQL select statement. What would be the result if you execute the following SQL statement?
UPDATE users SET Rank = "Senior"
item.choice: Nothing as you did not specify which row needs to be updated.
All users will be promoted to the rank Senior.
Error as you did not specify which row needs to be updated.
item.correct_answer: All users will be promoted to the rank Senior.
item.hint: By default SQL will affect all rows unless specified otherwise.
